text.tspan: . . . but it is not totally back to the future.
The world has been transformed in other ways. By
2030, majorities in most countries will be middle-class,
not poor, which has been the condition of most people
. . . and the pace of technological change will
Absorption of new technologies by Americans has
become much more rapid. The absorption rate in
developing states is also quickening, allowing these
states to leapfrog stages of development that advanced
Global population in urban areas is expanding
Every year, 65 million people are added to the world’s
urban population, equivalent to adding seven cities the
size of Chicago or ve the size of London annually.
The world is transforming at an unprecedented rate . . .
As the graph below shows, it took
to double GDP per capita, with about 9 million people
and 60 years with a few tens of million people . . . but
are doing this at a scale and pace not
seen before: 100 times the people than Britain and in
one tenth the time. By 2030 Asia will be well on its
way to returning to being the world’s powerhouse, just
Average increase in percentage point share of global GDP, per decade
